awd_abstract_narration:
As a part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds research and innovative resources for use in a variety of settings. In this project, the primary goal of Geo-literacy Education in Micronesia is to demonstrate the potential for effective intergenerational, informal learning and development of geo-literacy through an Informal STEM Learning Team (ISLT) model for Pacific island communities. This will be accomplished by means of a suite of six informal learning modules that blend local/Indigenous approaches, Western STEM knowledge systems, and active learning. 

This project will be implemented across 12 select communities in the Republic of Palau, the Federated States of Micronesia - which consists of the four States of Chuuk, Kosrae, Pohnpei, and Yap - and the Republic of the Marshall Islands. Jointly, these entities are referred to as the Freely Associated States (FAS). Geo-literacy refers to combining both local knowledge and Western STEM into a synthesized understanding of the world as a set of interconnected, dynamic physical, biological, and social systems, and using this integrated knowledge to make informed decisions. Applications include natural resource management, conservation, and disaster risk reduction. The project will: (1) demonstrate that the recruitment and development of an ISLT model is an effective method of engaging communities in geo-literacy activities; (2) increase geo-literacy knowledge and advocacy skills of ISLT participants; (3) produce and disseminate geo-literacy educational materials and resources (e.g., place-based teaching guides, geospatial data systems, educational apps, 2-D and 3-D models, and digital maps); and (4) provide evidence that FAS residents use these geo-literacy educational materials and resources to positively influence decision-making.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

inst.inst_name: Pacific Resources for Education and Learning

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Pacific Resources for Education and Learning

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Geo-literacy Education in Micronesia (GEM) worked to demonstrate the potential for effective intergenerational, informal learning and development of geo-literacy through an Informal STEM Learning Team (ISLeT) in Pacific island communities. GEM started in 2016 and brought together 30 ISLeTs across the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia (Kosrae, Pohnpei, Chuuk, and Yap), and Palau. Every product and event co-created by our ISLeTs is meant to help both the creators and audience use the ?texts? of our lands, waters, and skies to make better decisions for ourselves, our communities, and our futures.

We humbly acknowledge the elders, traditional leaders, and leaders of the church and government that have supported GEM since its beginning and all along the way. Thank you for your presence, your interest in GEM, and your willingness to share with our ISLeTs and with us a part of who you are and your cultures.

Intellectual Merit

While the GEM region is unique in its geographic size, cultural diversity, and political configurations, the ISLeT model has many features that serve as models for other place-based geo-literacy efforts. Even though GEM has a principal conceptual focus in geoscience, it took a broad approach in practice: the specific STEM domain that is relevant to any Module project depended on what the ISLET choses to focus on. For example, the Geoscience in Education ISLeT in Kosrae was interested in food preparation and preservation techniques? cultural domains of knowledge that are connected to ethnobotany, chemistry, ethnomathematics, and Indigenous technology? and extended into deeper research into breadfruit varieties and the stories surrounding this critical food source. The Geoscience in Education ISLeT in Pohnpei was interested in understanding the importance of river ecosystems in their community, inviting connections to hydrology, ethnobotany, and language. As the ISLeTs worked to collect stories and create booklets, posters, videos, and public signage, more was revealed about how ISLeT members conceptualize geoscience within their own community and ecological relationships. 

At the outset, researchers were expecting to explore how print literacy can help understand geo-literacy. Through ISLeT-led research and product development, a more holistic understanding of literacy came into view. Understanding geo-literacy led to building phenology observation skills; stories and discussion with elders about signs in the land, skies, and waters; studies of seasons and seasonal shifts and practices. These ways of ?reading? the skies, lands, and waters to make decisions demonstrate literacy. This form of literacy is not restricted to only written forms of language, but calls on multiple tools for communication, such as images, music and chant, or observation of natural phenomena. Geo-literate individuals can make decisions informed by multiple knowledges that shape communities to meet future practical and ethical challenges. They take the familiar way of doing something, interpret the standard, and redesign or transform it into a tool that meets current and future needs. In GEM, this pattern of literacy emerged as students, elders, and community partners engaged in the ?designed? to ?redesign? traditional ideas for current contexts = in discussion of traditional understandings and current pursuit for renaissance of fairo/respect in Chuuk; in the new uses of place names in Kosrae; in investigations into shifting harvest festival practices in Pohnpei; in continual refashioning and reinvention of traditional weaving and food-making practices in the Marshall Islands. 

As geo-literacy increased, the ISLeT approach gave us a deeper understanding of the interconnected systems that impact our daily choices and how geo-literacy helps us to better understand how those daily choices result in larger outcomes. Geo-literacy helps us contextualize the decisions and outcomes by asking critical questions. We learned that this increased engagement in geo-literacy is cultivating confidence and pride in their places, languages, and knowledges. ISLeT and broader community members are recognizing that their knowledge is science and valuable. These positive connections can be critical tools in supporting youth, in particular, as they make decisions about careers, family, and everyday life choices.

Broader Impacts

GEM showed an impact beyond STEM and traditional academia. Within project staff and ISLeT members, there is the realization of the scope of geo-literacy. Anyone has the potential to continue developing his or her own geo-literacy. In fact, it is our responsibility as community members to deepen our own geo-literacy throughout our lives and intentionally teach what we know to others. Deepening one?s own geo-literacy is a lifelong process that engages us at all stages. In documenting evidence of the impact GEM products have on decision-making, our approach was to conduct focus group dialogs in the vernacular, allowing for project participants directly involved in product development to reflect on and share their perspectives without translation, at least initially. This approach was intended to better capture Micronesian ways of understanding geography, ecology, and place, and how their perspectives and decision-making have changed. 

https://gem.prel.org/


Last Modified: 01/25/2023
Modified by: Corrin Barros

Images (1 of )
  • Youth from the Island Explorer ISLeT in the Marshall Islands display posters of their research into the storied places and cultural practices on Mejit Atoll.
    Corrin Barros
    Creative Commons
    Corrin Barros
    Youth from the Island Explorer ISLeT in RMI
  • Youth from Nanpei Memorial High School worked with Conservation Society of Pohnpei on researching traditional sakau ceremonial roles and responsibilities when hosting a chief in a community meeting house.
    Canita Rilometo Nakamura
    Creative Commons
    Corrin Barros
    Youth presenting sakau in the nahs with the Pohnpei Geoscience in Conservation ISLeT
  • As part of the Island Explorer ISLeT in Yap, KORC (Kids of Ruu Community) convened Disaster Risk Management Plan summit to help the Fais community on Waqab plan for typhoons, drought, and increase sanitation.
    Caroline Dabugsiy
    Creative Commons
    Corrin Barros
    Youth of Kids of Ruu Community at a summit on disaster management
  • Youth in Pollap (Chuuk) working together on a weaving piece after learning techniques from elders as part of the Island Explorer ISLeT.
    Paulina Yourupi-Sandy
    Creative Commons
    Corrin Barros
    Youth in Pollap learn weaving and respect, Island Explorer ISLeT
  • Youth in Kosrae install 75 place name signs around Malem village with the Island Observer ISLeT
    Joyminda George
    Creative Commons
    Corrin Barros
    Youth in Kosrae install place name signs with the Island Observer ISLeT
  • Melekeok Conservation Network and Melekeok ElementarySchool held a Geo-Literacy Summer Camp for 20 youth to explore the places and stories of Ngardok Nature Reserve and Ngermedellim Marine Sanctuary.
    Koh Ming Wei
    Creative Commons
    Corrin Barros
    Youth explore Ngardok Nature Reserve with the Palau Geoscience in Conservation ISLeT
